repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - First, Second, Third, and Fourth
            Poverty Reduction Support Operations Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, Third and
            Fourth Poverty Reduction Support Operations (PRSO) Project
            for Georgia were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: first,
            strong Government ownership of the reform program was
            crucial to the success and rapid pace of the PRSO series.
            The authorities took the lead in identifying and
            implementing the reform program, with the Bank playing a
            catalytic and supportive role in identifying ways to enhance
            what the Government had already decided to implement on an
            accelerated time schedule. Second, the strong focus of the
            Government on results was vital in driving implementation of
            the reform agenda. The authorities were sharply focused on
            achieving specific development outcomes and results, and the
            PRSO team supported the authorities in developing a detailed
            set of monitorable outcome indicators to track results from
            implementation of the reform program. Third, the
            programmatic approach afforded important flexibility to
            advance and deepen reform implementation in several areas
            and reduce the scope of or provide additional time for
            implementation in other areas. Fourth, strong donor
            coordination to strengthen the Government's
            implementation capacity was essential. The Bank's
            projects and other donors provided important technical
            assistance to build capacity in key areas. Areas in which
            Bank projects complemented the reforms supported by the PRSO
            series included public sector reform, education, and health
            care. Finally, reform progress can be achieved in areas
            without a clear reform champion if the area is selected
            carefully and if a flexible approach is adopted. A number of
            areas in serious need of reform, including external audit,
            civil service and procurement, lacked a clear reform
            champion. Given that the PRSO program was broad and
            ambitious, the Bank was selective in pursuing challenging
            reform areas that lacked a reform champion.

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Proposed supplemental credit to
            Georgia for the fourth poverty reduction support operation

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Poverty Reduction Support
            Operation (PRSO) for Georgia will provide supplemental
            budget support to the Government to help efforts to sustain
            implementation of the PRSO program in the face of
            unanticipated budget constraints associated with the August
            2008 conflict. The PRSO reform program focuses on four
            critical reform pillars: (i) strengthening public sector
            accountability, efficiency, and transparency; (ii) improving
            electricity and gas sector services; (iii) improving the
            environment for private sector development; and (iv)
            improving social protection, education, and health care
            services. The reforms aim at developing a dynamic and
            competitive private sector as the main engine of growth,
            with the state playing a supportive role by providing basic
            public goods and services. These development strategies,
            reflected in Georgia's poverty reduction strategy paper
            (PRSP), have served the country well. Driven by rapidly
            rising foreign direct investment (FDI) flows of about $1.5
            billion per year, which translated into domestic investment
            of 28 percent of gross domestic product (GDP), GDP growth
            averaged 10.5 percent per year over the last three years and
            reached 12.4 percent in 2007. During the same period,
            inflation was on average 8.7 percent per year, though it
            accelerated to 11 percent in 2007. Private capital inflows
            financed the large external current account deficit while
            international reserves increased from $881 million in 2006
            to $1,361 million in 2007, and to $1,550 million by end-July
            2008 (or about 2.6 months of imports). At the same time,
            external debt declined from 46 percent of GDP in 2003 to
            16.7 percent in 2007.

repnme.cdata!: Georgia - Fourth Poverty Reduction Support Operation

abstracts.cdata!:
This program document presents the
            Fourth Poverty Reduction Support Operation (PRSO IV) and is
            intended to continue to support the Government of Georgia in
            the implementation of policy reforms in the areas of: (i)
            strengthening public sector accountability, efficiency, and
            transparency; (ii) improving electricity and gas sector
            services; (iii) improving the environment for private sector
            development; and (iv) improving social protection, education
            and health care services. PRSO IV will be the last of this
            PRSO series, although the Georgian authorities have
            indicated interest in a possible follow-up programmatic
            development policy credit series. At the beginning of the
            PRSO series, the then new administration faced enormous
            challenges, and the primary objective of the PRSO series was
            to support selected reforms necessary to pull Georgia out of
            a failing state scenario and to mitigate the risks of
            derailment in of the reform process. For operational
            purposes, the program is organized into four pillars: (i)
            strengthening public sector accountability, efficiency, and
            transparency; (ii) improving electricity and gas sector
            services; (iii) improving the environment for private sector
            development; and (iv) improving social protection, education
            and health care services.
